comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1:

See review instructions at https://gist.github.com/jjelinek/4cab26f74ef9395c860e93eb799e0f8b

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

Thanks for taking the first swing at this. Beyond what I have below the only other question I have is is there some way we can add an attribute to the functions such that gcc won't complain about the unused function so that way we can get out of updating and gagging this warning in all of these Makefiles? It's never fun to have to.

Patch Set 1:

I agree with the points that Robert raised.

Waiting for a clean build to finish and then I'll upload a new CR.

This has all been pretty helpful thanks. I still have some confusion on the acpi_strtoul bit, but once that's clarified, I think we'll be in good shape.

Change has been successfully merged by Jerry Jelinek

Can you confirm that the reason AE_SAME_HANDLER is okay here is because we may end up calling acpica_install_handlers() multiple times and therefore if we already have the same handler registered, then we're in okay shape as we've already been here?
Yes, I determined this by testing in my coal. see the AcpiEvInstallSpaceHandler() function.
Done
This maybe belongs in acpica/osl.c which seems to be where we have the other similar functions.
moved
Done
Why is the set_errno here? Is this being called from a system call path?
no, it is not in the syscall path, but that is how the function is defined, so if any of the Intel calling code wants to handle an error, checking errno is the way
Followed up in the moved code loc.

Two things here. First, I think this belongs in acpica/osl.c as that's where we have the AcpiOsExecute function.

More importantly, it seems like this needs to be actually waiting for any asynchronous tasks that are kicked off with AcpiOsExecute and so it should be doing a wait on the taskq.

a) moved
b) fixed
Done
Is there a reason for the // here and below?
change has been removed
Done

The comment in <util/strtolctype.h> says that new code should all be using the kernel <sys/ctype.h>. Can you go into more detail about why you used this, rather than sys/ctype.h? All of this should run in a context where we have that kernel ctype information available.
fixed the code to use sys/ctype.h (which is the correct solution and not what I originally had). This allows me to removed all of the Makefile changes which update the include file search paths.
Done
If we can use <sys/ctype.h> then we'll have the isprint macro as well.
removed
Done
In general, we prefer explicit comparisons, != NULL.
I had followed the existing code convention, but I went ahead and changed this.

So I spent some time following up in the code on this and I think I'm still a bit confused.. I don't see anything in the ACPI code that references our lwp_errno.

It also seems like the built in versions of this returns a uint32_t as opposed to a ulong_t and returns UINT32_MAX on error, if I'm reading this correctly.

a) I don't think anything in the existing code will ever refer to our lwp_errno since that is not how this function is defined and since nothing in the ACPI code is aware of our kernel implementation. However, that is really missing the point. Even if nothing in the existing code is looking at errno, that doesn't mean that nothing ever will in future builds and I feel that we would be leaving a time bomb by not following the convention for how this function is defined.

b) I don't understand this second comment. The built-in version of ddi_strtoul? The man page clearly states it returns an errno.

I think I figured out what you mean here. You are talking about how the callers are checking for an error on strtoul and how they assume that function returns an unsigned 32bit integer vs. an unsigned long. I will update the code to reflect that usage.
Before the return statement we need to check if the value is out of range of a uint32_t. So we should check if the value is >= ACPI_UINT32_MAX and then return it if it is.
